Tawang.title: Tawang, Arunachal Pradesh
info: Home to the Tawang Monastery, the largest monastery in India and the second largest in the world.
Known for its breathtaking high-altitude scenery, including Sela Pass and numerous glacial lakes.
The district is inhabited primarily by the Monpa people.
It was a focal point during the 1962 Sino-Indian War.
Its economy is largely dependent on tourism and agriculture.

tourist_places.name: Sela Pass
tourist_places.location: Between Tawang & West Kameng districts, Arunachal Pradesh

West Kameng.title: West Kameng, Arunachal Pradesh
info: The district headquarters is Bomdila, a town offering panoramic views of the Himalayas.
Home to diverse ethnic groups including the Monpa, Miji, Sherdukpen, Aka, and Khowa tribes.
Features the Eaglenest Wildlife Sanctuary, a prime bird-watching destination.
Dirang Valley is famous for its hot water springs and apple orchards.
The Bomdila Monastery is a significant spiritual center in the district.

East Kameng.title: East Kameng, Arunachal Pradesh
info: The district headquarters is Seppa.
The Kameng River flows through the district, offering opportunities for rafting and adventure sports.
Primarily inhabited by the Nyishi tribe.
Home to the Pakke Tiger Reserve, a crucial wildlife corridor.
The terrain is mostly mountainous, with a rich biodiversity.

Pakke Kessang.title: Pakke Kessang, Arunachal Pradesh
info: One of the newest districts, created in 2018 by bifurcating East Kameng.
Its headquarters is at Lemmi.
The district is named after the Pakke River and Kessang Hills.
Primarily inhabited by the Nyishi people.
The region is known for its lush forests and biodiversity.

tourist_places.name: Pakke Valley
tourist_places.location: Near Lemmi, Pakke Kessang, Arunachal Pradesh

Papum Pare.title: Papum Pare, Arunachal Pradesh
info: Contains the state capital, Itanagar, and the new legislative assembly at Naharlagun.
Itanagar is a historic city, identified with the ancient Mayapur.
The Ganga Lake (Gyakar Sinyi) is a popular recreational spot near the capital.
Primarily inhabited by the Nyishi and Mishing tribes.
The district is an administrative and educational hub for the state.

tourist_places.name: Ganga Lake (Gyakar Sinyi)
tourist_places.location: Near Itanagar, Papum Pare, Arunachal Pradesh

Lower Subansiri.title: Lower Subansiri, Arunachal Pradesh
info: The district headquarters is Ziro.
Ziro Valley is a UNESCO World Heritage Site candidate, known for its stunning landscapes and Apatani culture.
The Apatani tribe is famous for its unique sustainable agriculture and social forestry systems.
The district hosts the popular Ziro Music Festival annually.
It is a major producer of rice in the state.

Kra Daadi.title: Kra Daadi, Arunachal Pradesh
info: Carved out of Kurung Kumey district in 2015.
The district headquarters is Palin.
The name is derived from two local hills, Kra and Daadi.
It is primarily inhabited by the Nyishi tribe.
The district is known for its rugged terrain and rich traditional culture.

Kurung Kumey.title: Kurung Kumey, Arunachal Pradesh
info: The district headquarters is Koloriang.
Known for its extremely rugged and mountainous terrain, making it one of the most remote districts.
Primarily inhabited by the Nyishi and Bangru tribes.
The Kurung and Kumey are the main rivers flowing through the district.
The region has a rich oral tradition and vibrant folk culture.

Upper Subansiri.title: Upper Subansiri, Arunachal Pradesh
info: The district headquarters is Daporijo.
The Subansiri River, one of the largest tributaries of the Brahmaputra, flows through this district.
Inhabited by the Tagin, Nyishi, and Galo tribes.
The Menga Mandir (cave temple) is a significant local pilgrimage site.
Known for its cane and bamboo handicrafts.

tourist_places.name: Menga Mandir
tourist_places.location: Near Daporijo, Upper Subansiri, Arunachal Pradesh

West Siang.title: West Siang, Arunachal Pradesh
info: The district headquarters is Aalo (formerly Along).
The Siyom River meets the Siang (Brahmaputra) River in this district.
Primarily inhabited by the Galo tribe.
Known for its picturesque valleys and suspension bridges made of cane and bamboo.
The Ramakrishna Mission School in Aalo is a prominent educational institution.

tourist_places.name: Kane Wildlife Sanctuary
tourist_places.location: Near Aalo, West Siang, Arunachal Pradesh

Shi Yomi.title: Shi Yomi, Arunachal Pradesh
info: A new district created in 2018, carved out of West Siang.
Its headquarters is at Tato.
The district borders China and is of strategic importance.
The name is derived from the Shi and Yomi rivers.
Inhabited by the Memba, Adi, and Tagin tribes.

Siang.title: Siang, Arunachal Pradesh
info: Created in 2015 by bifurcating West Siang and East Siang districts.
The district headquarters is Boleng.
The mighty Siang River (Brahmaputra) flows through the heart of the district.
The region is known for its diverse Adi sub-tribes.
The landscape is dominated by river valleys and steep mountains.

Upper Siang.title: Upper Siang, Arunachal Pradesh
info: The district headquarters is Yingkiong.
The Siang River enters India from Tibet in this district.
Inhabited mainly by the Adi and Memba tribes.
Known for the Mouling National Park, a vast biosphere reserve.
The district is remote with pristine forests and a rugged landscape.

East Siang.title: East Siang, Arunachal Pradesh
info: The district headquarters, Pasighat, is the oldest administrative centre in Arunachal Pradesh.
Considered the 'Gateway to Arunachal Pradesh'.
The Siang River flows through Pasighat before entering Assam.
Primarily inhabited by the Adi tribe.
The Daying Ering Wildlife Sanctuary is located on an island in the Siang River.

Lower Siang.title: Lower Siang, Arunachal Pradesh
info: Formally created in 2017 with its headquarters at Likabali.
The district was carved out of West Siang and East Siang districts.
Primarily inhabited by the Galo tribe.
Malinithan, an archaeological site with ancient temple ruins, is a major attraction.
The region lies in the foothills of the Himalayas.

Lepa Rada.title: Lepa Rada, Arunachal Pradesh
info: A new district created in 2018 from Lower Siang district.
The district headquarters is Basar.
Inhabited by the Galo tribe.
Basar is known for its 'GRK' (Gumin Rigo Kwgo) festivals and community-based initiatives.
The district has a strong focus on preserving its indigenous culture and traditions.

Kamle.title: Kamle, Arunachal Pradesh
info: Inaugurated in 2017, carved out of Upper and Lower Subansiri districts.
The district headquarters is Raga.
Primarily inhabited by the Nyishi tribe.
The Kamle River flows through the district.
The district was created to improve administration in the remote region.

Lower Dibang Valley.title: Lower Dibang Valley, Arunachal Pradesh
info: The district headquarters is Roing.
Known for its stunning natural beauty, including lakes, waterfalls, and river valleys.
Primarily inhabited by the Idu Mishmi tribe.
The Bhismaknagar archaeological site contains ruins of an ancient fort.
Mehao Wildlife Sanctuary is located in this district.

tourist_places.name: Mayudia Pass
tourist_places.location: Near Roing, Lower Dibang Valley, Arunachal Pradesh

Upper Dibang Valley.title: Upper Dibang Valley, Arunachal Pradesh
info: The district headquarters is Anini.
It is the largest district in Arunachal Pradesh by area but the least populated district in India.
Primarily inhabited by the Idu Mishmi (Mishmi) tribe.
The district is extremely remote and known for its pristine, untouched landscapes.
It is a hotspot of biodiversity with rare flora and fauna.

tourist_places.name: Anini Town
tourist_places.location: Anini, Upper Dibang Valley, Arunachal Pradesh

Anjaw.title: Anjaw, Arunachal Pradesh
info: The district headquarters is Hawai.
It is the easternmost district of India.
The Lohit River flows through the district.
Known for the Kibithu and Walong towns, which were sites of major battles during the 1962 war.
Inhabited by the Mishmi and Meyor tribes.

Lohit.title: Lohit, Arunachal Pradesh
info: The district headquarters is Tezu.
Famous for the Parshuram Kund, a major Hindu pilgrimage site that attracts devotees from all over India.
The Lohit River gives the district its name.
Inhabited by the Mishmi, Adi, and Khamti tribes.
Tezu is known for its vibrant Mishmi culture.

Namsai.title: Namsai, Arunachal Pradesh
info: Created in 2014 by bifurcating Lohit district.
The district headquarters is Namsai town.
Known for the Golden Pagoda (Kongmu Kham), a beautiful Buddhist monastery.
Primarily inhabited by the Khamti and Singpho tribes.
The district is a major producer of tea in Arunachal Pradesh.

Changlang.title: Changlang, Arunachal Pradesh
info: The district headquarters is Changlang town.
It shares an international border with Myanmar.
Home to the Namdapha National Park, a major biodiversity hotspot in the Eastern Himalayas.
Inhabited by the Tangsa, Tutsa, and Singpho tribes.
The historic Stilwell Road, built during World War II, passes through this district.

Tirap.title: Tirap, Arunachal Pradesh
info: The district headquarters is Khonsa.
It shares a border with Myanmar and the state of Nagaland.
Primarily inhabited by the Nocte, Wancho, and Tutsa tribes.
The district is known for its rich tribal culture and traditional village systems.
It has faced insurgency issues in the past.

Longding.title: Longding, Arunachal Pradesh
info: Carved out of Tirap district in 2012.
The district headquarters is Longding town.
Primarily inhabited by the Wancho tribe, known for their unique culture and traditions.
The Wancho are famous for their wood carvings and beadwork.
The district shares a border with Myanmar and Nagaland.
